ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FULL-TIME NATIONAL SERVICE
(Variation of period)


    1. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether there is any plan to vary the period for full-time National Service.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, MINDEF has no plans to vary the period of National Service.

    Mr Chandra Das, the Chairman of the Government Parliamentary Committee for Defence and Foreign Affairs, had suggested that MINDEF consider the possibility of shortening the National Service period.

    The period of active National Service serves two purposes. Firstly, the national servicemen are trained for their operational roles. They learn individual skills, whether they are infantrymen, section leaders or platoon commanders. They also train as units, in order to fight as a team, at the platoon, company or battalion levels or beyond. This consumes a large part of the 2 or 2 1/2 years of active National Service.

    Secondly, after they are fully trained, national servicemen form the bulk of the standing force available to the SAF. This is a force in being, whose very existence deters potential threats. It is immediately available to deal with emergencies, or to

Column: 1032

cope with periods of tension requiring higher states of readiness. Most countries meet this requirement through a regular army. The SAF, being a citizen army, meets it using national servicemen.

    This is not to underestimate the importance of reservists as combat ready soldiers. In war, reservists will form the backbone of the SAF. But in many other situations short of war, mobilising the reservists would disrupt the economy and raise tensions. The standing force of national servicemen enables us to cope with such situations.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): As we are in fact in peacetime now and taking into account the interruption to students going into university and also in their job careers, is there not a case to reduce the period of full-time National Service?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have just answered that question. Every day spent in National Service is a day spent away from the economy. As the Minister also responsible for trade and industry, I am acutely aware of the manpower shortage in the economy, and how much of a contribution national servicemen could make if they were not required to serve in the SAF. But it is a balance between how much security we want to have and how much economic growth and wealth we want to produce. You can have National Service for six or eight months and then allow everybody to go out and earn a living. It is one extra year plus of economic production from each soldier who does that, not an insignificant amount.

    But if we do not have enough in the SAF with all the wealth in the world, I am not sure whether, firstly, there will be confidence in the security of the country, and, secondly, if some threat did materialise, whether all this might not be taken away from us. One of the reasons people have confidence in Singapore is that the SAF is here. It is well-trained, it is professional and, without being an onerous burden on the economy, has been able to guarantee security and therefore confidence.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, as I understand it, in Switzerland, they have, in the first

Column: 1033

instance, national service for something like 19 weeks. In the case of West Germany, they have full-time national service for a period of about nine months. If these countries, which are in places where they have undergone two world wars, can have such short full-time national service, why can we not have it here?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Swiss, as Mr Chiam has pointed out, have a few weeks of national service. The Germans do not have nine months. They have 15 months. In fact, until the recent dramatic developments in East Germany and Eastern Europe, they were talking about pushing it to 18 months, for precisely the same reason that we have to keep our national service period, namely, not enough German babies were born, not enough soldiers, and you need a longer period to maintain that same size of standing force. Now that situation has changed. There is no more talk of extending national service in Germany from 15 to 18 months.

    Our situation has not similarly changed. We have not seen a total revision of the landscape in the Asia Pacific. There has not been a change of government, for example, in Indochina or in China. There has not been a change in the strategic relationships in the region. I will be answering this more fully when I address Dr Lee's Question shortly. But there is a difference between a reservist force which you can call up in an emergency, and a force in being which is there all the time. I have to do nothing extra if tension rises, because I already have the troops at the ready and prepared deal with against any eventuality.

    It is easy fo us to say that in a tension period, we will call them back from the reserve, and they will come back within 12 hours. We can get them. They can be mobilised, equipped, deployed, all will be well. In a real tension, to decide to mobilise reserves is a very big decision. Firstly, it raises the temperature because obviously you must be going to war. You are calling the troops back. Secondly, it is disruptive on the economy because you have to pull people out from jobs. There will be companies whose operations will

Column: 1034

be upset. Thirdly, psychologically, the country gears itself up, expecting to come to the crunch. Nothing happens, it comes back down again. The next time we need to build up is more difficult.

    I do not know if the Member is familiar with military history but I think Dr Ong would be. One of the reasons why the Israelis were caught by surprise in the 1973 war was that they had, on several previous occasions just before that, false alarms, mobilised and had to demobilise. When the actual day came, despite the warning signs, this was one of the factors which led them not to move. The Egyptians had cried wolf on their behalf once too often, and very successfully. That is why it is important for us to have a standing force. Two years' national service means, at most, about a Division plus of troops to defend the whole of Singapore and to be available in case of any peacetime contingency. That is one reason.

    The second reason why you cannot bring the period down very drastically is the way we train our soldiers. We want to give them not just a basic proficiency but as much competence as possible to enable them to look after themselves and the troops under their command in war. You can in 19 weeks train a soldier to fire a rifle or man a howitzer. I do not think you can train him to be an officer to lead men, or even if you could try to train him, I do not think any men will follow him.

    The Swiss do it because they do not see the threat of immediate war. Their situation is different. They are in the middle of Western Europe. They are surrounded on all sides by EC countries. They believe that this is one chance in a million and if it comes then they mobilise. We are in Southeast Asia. I think the chances are considerably more than one in a million and we should be careful about following the same example. The Germans did not follow the Swiss example. Can we?

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, does the Minister see any immediate danger of war in Singapore?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, of course not. But one of the reasons for that is we have the SAF and therefore when we

Column: 1035

see developments in the region, we can afford to take a relaxed and tranquil approach to it. We can observe developments with equanimity and without having to be tense with the finger on the trigger all the time.

DEFENCE EXPENDITURE
(Review)


    2. Dr Lee Siew-Choh asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether, in the light of the easing of tension all over the world, the Government has any plan to review the present expenditure on defence.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government constantly reviews its defence expenditure to ensure that it gets the best value for every dollar spent. It strives to keep the SAF lean and efficient, in order to make best use of scarce manpower and limited funds for the security of the nation.

    The momentous changes in the strategic situation in Europe, and the corresponding reduction of tension between NATO and the Warsaw Pact, have not been followed by any similar upheaval in the Asia Pacific. The US Defence Secretary, Mr Dick Cheney, said recently in the Philippines that while some cuts in the US military forces in Asia were being considered, the numbers would be relatively modest, as he did not "see the equivalent kind of change in Asia and the Pacific that we've seen in Europe".

    In any case, Singapore has never based its defence policy on countering an opposing military bloc, unlike NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Our policy has always been to deter all potential aggressors, whoever they may be, from attacking or intimidating us.

    Even if improved relations between the US and USSR lead the two superpowers to reduce their military forces in the region, it does not follow that other regional causes for tension and conflict will therefore disappear. These are regional causes, unrelated to the US and USSR.

Column: 1036



    The outcome of the Cambodian conflict is not yet certain, even though the war appears to be drawing to a close.

    The territorial disputes over the Spratlys and Paracels islands have nothing to do with superpower rivalry. They are actually disputes over who owns the oil or gas which may lie undiscovered in the waters surrounding these islands. These disputes have been muted by the US presence in the region, including their military bases in the Philippines, Japan and South Korea.

    If the US significantly cuts back its military forces in the region, this will not be a signal for Singapore also to reduce our forces. It will be reason for concern over a potentially destabilising change in the regional balance of power, one which may lead to other significant powers playing a more active role in the region.

    Singapore is not alone in this view. The Malaysian Government shares this perspective. For example, Prime Minister Dr Mahathir Mohammed has said that it would be premature for the US to consider withdrawal from the bases in the Philippines, despite the apparent reduction in regional tensions brought on by heightened prospects of a Cambodian settlement and new peace overtures from the Soviet Union.

    The Malaysian Armed Forces' Chief of Intelligence, General Datuk Abdul Rashid Raja, also recently expressed concern over the Spratlys and the Paracels, and the possibility that China may become more aggressive if the US reduces its role in the region. He said "the situation around us is not stable yet. The smaller countries still cannot feel secure yet. America's presence is certainly needed at least to balance other powers in the region". This is the Malaysian Armed Forces' Chief of Intelligence. He was interviewed in Utusan Malaysia on 2nd February 1990 and the report was carried in the Straits Times last week.

    No other ASEAN country is slashing its defence expenditures, demobilising its armed forces, or acting on the assumption that it no longer faces any external security threats. It would be foolhardy for Singapore alone to do so. The Government therefore intends to maintain the limit on

Column: 1037

defence expenditure at 6% of the Gross Domestic Product. This figure has remained unchanged for many years. The money is needed to train troops, to operate, maintain and upgrade equipment and weapons, and to pay regular servicemen salaries commensurate with what they can earn in other civilian jobs. All this costs more each year.

    With prudent financial management, the Government has always been able to fund all its other expenditures besides defence, without having to sacrifice any projects. However, this does not mean that MINDEF should automatically spend the entire 6% of GDP available for defence each year. The GDP is much larger now than it was a decade ago. A large part of the SAF has already been built up. MINDEF now has more flexibility to time the upgrading and replacement of SAF equipment and weapons, in order to get the best possible value for money. Depending on the SAF's needs, in some years we may not require to spend the entire 6% which has been set aside for defence. This will happen more often if the cost of military equipment does not escalate too fast, and if the economy continues to grow rapidly.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Does Singapore envisage any territorial disputes with other countries surrounding it in ASEAN?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore has no territorial ambitions. But I am sure the Members will have heard of Horsburgh Lighthouse or Pedra Branca belonging to Singapore over which from time to time issues have arisen with the Malaysian government.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Does it mean from what the Minister says that this dispute could lead to possible clashes and war in future?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Government does not intend to go to war with anybody, and the SAF is required whether or not we own Pedra Branca.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: If other ASEAN countries should reduce their defence expenditure, would Singapore do the same?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is a purely hypothetical question.

Column: 1038



     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: It is the Minister who has been giving us a lot of hypothetical issues. In fact, what I ask the Minister is whether there is any way of reducing defence expenditure without jeopardising the security of Singapore.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, we seek such ways all the time. Mindef works very hard at making sure it only spends money on what it needs. And if the Member has any further ideas on how to improve our defence capability and save money, we will be happy to hear from him.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: May I suggest then, Sir, that the Minister form a high-powered committee to investigate into how we can reduce such defence expenditure and make the report public to the people of Singapore.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, every year during the Committee of Supply, the defence budget is up for debate. And every year Members have raised queries as to what we are doing, whether we need to do it, how we can do better. Dr Lee is a Member of this House and I look forward to hearing from him during the Committee of Supply.

HDB'S RELOCATION PROGRAMME IN TIONG BAHRU GRC


    3. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether the subsequent phases of the Housing and Development Board's relocation programme in Tiong Bahru GRC will be undertaken, and, if so, when.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The Housing and Development Board plans to implement the next phase, Phase IB, of the Relocation Programme over three years from 1990 to 1992. A total of 256 blocks of rental flats have been included under Phase IB. Eight blocks of rental flats in Tiong Bahru GRC will be affected by the Relocation Programme in 1991. HDB has not decided on the subsequent phases of the Relocation Programme.

Column: 1039



     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): Sir, what steps will be taken to minimize dislocation to the lives of particularly old people who are living in these flats?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Relocation Programme, affected tenants will be granted priority allocation of either rental flats or purchase flats. This will minimize any inconvenience to the affected tenants of these rental flats because they would be able to find alternative accommodation as close as possible to their original residence. In the case of those who want to buy flats, they will also get priority when flats are available in the nearby area.

INDEPENDENT SCHOOLS
(Financial support schemes)


    4. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Education if he will give details of the various financial support schemes for independent school fees and the number of applications.

     The Minister for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Ministry of Education administers a financial support scheme to assist students in independent schools who need financial assistance to pay the school fees.

    The income eligibility criteria for financial assistance are as follows:

    (i) For full subsidy of school fees, the monthly household income should be $800 or less, or the household income per dependent child should be $400 or less; and

    (ii) For half-subsidy of school fees, the monthly household income should be between $801 and $1,200, or the household income per dependent child should be between $401 and $600.

    Sir, for 1990, a total of 402 students from the six independent schools, comprising 8.4% of the 4,785 pupils who have to pay the new fees, applied for financial assistance. 225 students were granted the full subsidy and 126 students were granted half subsidy of school fees. Of the 51 applicants who did not qualify for assistance, 39 students were granted assistance

Column: 1040

by the independent schools under the various schemes administered by the schools. In other words, 390 pupils or 97% of those applying were granted financial assistance either by the Government or directly by the schools.

    In addition to the above financial assistance scheme, students in independent schools can also apply for assistance under the Secondary School Bursary Scheme and the Grant and Loan of Textbooks Scheme which are open to all secondary school students in Singapore. The Secondary School Bursary Scheme grants remission of school fees and an award of $120 per annum. The Grants and Loan of Textbooks Scheme helps pupils to get the textbooks which they need for their studies.

    For 1990, 19 students from the six independent schools were awarded bursaries. No student applied for assistance under the Grant and Loan of Textbooks Scheme.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tiong Bahru GRC): Two supplementary questions, Sir. The first question is on the low level of applications. Does it not indicate that the means criterion is too stringent? The second question is if the Minister is confident that not many Singaporeans will apply for assistance, will he be more liberal with the criteria and raise the level of income?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, with regard to the first question, the impression could be that the criterion is too strict or that not many pupils require assistance. With regard to the second question, the Ministry, together with the independent schools, keeps the situation under review all the time. I think for this year the situation is well in hand. But if the need arises, the Ministry will obviously review the scheme and raise the criteria if this is necessary.

CIVICS/MORAL EDUCATION PROGRAMME
(Progress report)


    5. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Education what progress his Ministry has made with respect to the new civics/moral education programme follow-

Column: 1041

ing the decision to discontinue the teaching of religious knowledge as a compulsory subject in the upper secondary school curriculum.

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Mr Speaker, Sir, a Steering Committee, comprising Specialists from the Ministry of Education and the Institute of Education as well as school principals, has been formed to develop a syllabus and textbooks for the new Civics/Moral Education programme which will be taught in the upper levels of secondary schools in place of Religious Knowledge.

    This Committee has formulated a draft framework for the syllabus and this framework will be discussed at the Schools Council Meeting this Saturday, 24th February. As the subject is likely to be of wide interest and in order that the Ministry may have the benefit of informed opinion, I have also sent the draft framework to Dr Tan Cheng Bock, Chairman of the Government Parliamentary Committee on Education, and to Mr Chandra Das, Chairman of the Supervisory Panel of the Feedback Unit. Dr Tan and Mr Das will be organising meetings in order to obtain feedback on the draft framework. Their views will be communicated to the Ministry by June this year.

    This will enable the Ministry to finalise the curriculum in time to introduce the new Civics/Moral Education programme in 1992 starting with the secondary III pupils.

ILLEGAL FOOD MANUFACTURERS
(More severe action against)


    6. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for the Environment, (a) since the deterrence of adverse publicity and the quantum of fine do not, despite his Ministry's previous assurance to this House, seem to be effective against illegal food manufacturers who do not deal directly with consumers, whether he will consider other more stringent measures against such manufacturers; and (b) whether he will also consider taking more severe action against food vendors selling cooked food to consumers, if such vendors obtain their supplies of cooked food from illegal or unhygienic food manufacturers.

Column: 1042



     The Acting Minister for the Environment (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, widespread publicity and the prosecution of persons involved in illegal food manufacturing have been effective in our enforcement efforts against illegal food manufacturing activities. Since October last year, operations against illegal food manufacturing activities have resulted in the closing down of 49 illegal food factories. Another 34 such factories were found abandoned by illegal operators. My Ministry's operation against illegal food manufacturers will continue.

    Illegal food manufacturers can be imprisoned up to three months and fined up to a total of $6,000, even for the first offence. So far, one offender was jailed for four weeks. My Ministry will press for more offenders to be jailed in order that we can put an end to such illegal activities. In the meantime, officers from the Food Control Department of my Ministry will continue to step up its enforcement actions to search and close down illegal food manufacturers and bring the offenders to Court. Property owners will also be prosecuted if they knowingly allow their premises to be used for food manufacturing without a licence.

    As for food vendors selling food obtained from illegal food manufacturers, they may lose their licence if they are caught. All licensed food vendors have been adequately warned that they must obtain pre-prepared food or cooked food only from licensed food manufacturers. This is a condition of their licence. Officers from my Ministry conduct checks to ensure that this condition is strictly followed.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Two supplementary questions, Sir. What is the penalty for property owners who knowingly allow their premises to be used for food manufacturing without a licence? And second question, how many licensed food vendors who are found selling food obtained from illegal food manufacturers have their licence revoked?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Mr Speaker, Sir, property owners who knowingly allow their premises to be used as illegal food manufacturing establishments will be

Column: 1043

prosecuted under the Environmental Public Health Act. The penalty on conviction for the first offence is a fine not exceeding $1,000; for the second and the subsequent offence, and if they are convicted, a fine of not exceeding $4,000 or to an imprisonment term of not more than three months, or maybe to both imprisonment and fine. So far, Sir, the licence of a food centre stallholder was revoked last month when it was found that she had obtained the food from an illegal source.

MRT STATIONS
(Adjacent bus interchanges)


    7. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for Communications and Information (a) how many Mass Rapid Transit stations now have adjacent bus interchanges; and (b) whether there are other MRT stations which could have adjacent bus interchanges but do not have them, and, if so, why.
